</items>     <image rdf:resource="http://gmane.org/img/gmane-25t.png"/>     <textinput rdf:resource=""/>   </channel>   <image rdf:about="http://gmane.org/img/gmane-25t.png">     <title>Gmane</title>     <url>http://gmane.org/img/gmane-25t.png</url>     <link>http://gmane.org</link>   </image>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115859">     <title>Re: [ANN] ZeroBrane Studio 1.0</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115859</link>     <description><pre>Hi Philipp (and others),   No, it's not. The tracking was turned off last time when it was pointed to me, but the link itself had the tracking component, which I didn't see when I copied it. My apologies.  Paul.   </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Paul K</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-20T00:24:48</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115858">     <title>Re: OP_TAILCALL versus OP_CALL question</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115858</link>     <description><pre> I haven't yet figured out how to properly implement OP_TAILCALL in a JITed function. OP_CALL appears to work unless there is deep recursion. The Lua5.3 tests do fail in calls.lua - the failure occurs after about 4200 calls in my environment.  Regards Dibyendu   </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Dibyendu Majumdar</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-20T00:23:58</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115857">     <title>Re: [ANN] ZeroBrane Studio 1.0</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115857</link>     <description><pre>Am 20.03.2015 um 00:25 schr\ufffd\ufffdbte Paul K:  It seems your mail provider is hijacking your URLs (and links in the  HTML part). Is that intentional?  Philipp      </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Philipp Janda</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-20T00:07:31</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115856">     <title>Re: OP_TAILCALL versus OP_CALL question</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115856</link>     <description><pre> If you do that, code that works will start producing stack overflows.  </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Hisham</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-19T23:41:42</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115855">     <title>[ANN] ZeroBrane Studio 1.0</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115855</link>     <description><pre>Hi All,  ZeroBrane Studio is a lightweight Lua IDE with code completion, syntax highlighting, remote debugger, code analyzer, live coding, integration with various Lua engines, and support for Lua 5.1, 5.2, 5.3, and LuaJIT.  The new version includes the following improvements (full details are in the changelog [1]):  - Added directory mapping to the project tree. - Added `Run to Cursor`. - Added ability to set/unset start file for a project. - Added `staticanalyzer.infervalue` to enable deeper/slower analysis; this is based on lua-inspect and includes analysis for field values and evaluated code.  Installation packages for Windows, OSX, and Linux are available on the project website: http://studio.zerobrane.com &lt;http://mandrillapp.com/track/click/30107008/studio.zerobrane.com?p=eyJzIjoicXZGRlFoMXVhU2JISzRabHNLRTBVLTdITldrIiwidiI6MSwicCI6IntcInVcIjozMDEwNzAwOCxcInZcIjoxLFwidXJsXCI6XCJodHRwOlxcXC9cXFwvc3R1ZGlvLnplcm9icmFuZS5jb21cIixcImlkXCI6XCIyZDAyOWQ4MzlhY2Y0NmE5YWE4YmExMmEyYzhjMmQ4NlwiLFwidXJsX2lkc1wiOltcIm</pre></description>     <dc:creator>Paul K</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-19T23:25:50</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115854">     <title>OP_TAILCALL versus OP_CALL question</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115854</link>     <description><pre>Hi,  I was wondering if I can simply code for OP_CALL when the JIT encounters OP_TAILCALL - in a simple test it seems to work okay but am wondering if there might be something that means that I need to code OP_TAILCALL differently.  Thanks and Regards  Dibyendu   </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Dibyendu Majumdar</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-19T22:38:15</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115853">     <title>Re: [ANN] LuaRocks 2.2.1</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115853</link>     <description><pre> I used configure --lua-version=&lt;ver&gt; --lua-suffix=&lt;ver&gt; --versioned-rocks-dir  when I built luarocks, since I am using multiple versions of lua/luarocks.   When I run 'luarocks-5.2 install luarocks', it doesn't seem to include the version number.     </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Mike Schmitz</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-19T21:37:32</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115852">     <title>Re: [ANN] Lua for Windows v5.1.4-47 Released</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115852</link>     <description><pre>  Have you seen this? https://github.com/siffiejoe/prg-lr4win  It could take care of the Lua + LuaRocks installation part. </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Ignacio Burgue\ufffd\ufffdo</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-19T02:43:03</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115851">     <title>Re: [ANN] Lua for Windows v5.1.4-47 Released</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115851</link>     <description><pre>I would be glad to. Last time there was a zip file that you made for me. I have no experience setting up LuaRocks on Windows, so it would be very helpful.  Yeah I know... I should use it (it is used on 40+ computers everyday at my work and just keeps working so it falls in the "if it ain't broke don't fix it" category for me), but we have tried to get LuaDist going a few times and my main operating system is Linux, so I will accept most help and pull requests. I put all the files on GitHub now so that all you have to do is clone and install InnoSetup and compile the .iss script.  They are currently built with vc2005 which is ancient too, so the problem starts to stack up.  Should we simply cut our losses and switch to LuaDist even if all the modules are not there?  Any helpers available to build new binaries of the modules included? -- Regards, Ryan  Sent from my tablet On Mar 18, 2015 6:09 PM, "Hisham" &lt;h&lt; at &gt;hisham.hm&gt; wrote:  </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Ryan Pusztai</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-19T02:02:27</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115850">     <title>Re: [ANN] Lua for Windows v5.1.4-47 Released</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115850</link>     <description><pre> The version of LuaRocks that's included (2.0.2) is five years old... :(  https://github.com/keplerproject/luarocks/wiki/Release-history  Are there plans for an updated version?  </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Hisham</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-18T22:08:32</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115849">     <title>Re: [ANN] Lua for Windows v5.1.4-47 Released</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115849</link>     <description><pre>  I forgot to mention that you can find the release under the "Releases" https://github.com/rjpcomputing/luaforwindows/releases/tag/v5.1.4-47 -- Regards, Ryan </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Ryan Pusztai</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-18T19:56:52</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115848">     <title>[ANN] Lua for Windows v5.1.4-47 Released</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115848</link>     <description><pre>*WARNING*: GoogleCode is closing it's doors so this project has moved over to GitHub.  This is a simple release that moves the links in the installer over to GitHub. Also I committed all the files in hopes to get some help keeping the modules up to date.  We are proud to announce the next release of Lua for Windows (LfW). Read the changelog for more information. Enjoy. The project is hosted on GitHub.  Homepage:  http://github.com/rjpcomputing/luaforwindows  Description:  Lua for Windows is a 'batteries included environment' for the Lua scripting language on Windows.  Lua for Windows combines Lua binaries, Lua libraries with a Lua-capable editor in a single install package for the Microsoft Windows operating system. Lua for Windows contains everything you need to write, run and debug Lua scripts on Windows. A wide variety of libraries and examples are included that are ready to use with Microsoft Windows. Lua for Windows runs on Windows 2000 and newer versions of Windows. Lua and its associated libraries are</pre></description>     <dc:creator>Ryan Pusztai</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-18T19:46:06</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115847">     <title>Where Lua is used - Osmand PCB</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115847</link>     <description><pre>Osmand PCB, a PCB layout program for the Mac, supports Lua scripting. Osmand has free and low cost versions, and is for layout only (no schematic capture).  http://www.osmondpcb.com/index.html  --Tony </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Tony</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-18T17:19:50</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115846">     <title>[ANN] LuaRocks 2.2.1</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115846</link>     <description><pre>Hello list!  On behalf of the development community at the luarocks-developers mailing list, I'm happy to announce LuaRocks 2.2.1. LuaRocks is a package management system for Lua modules. (For more information, please visit http://luarocks.org )  http://luarocks.org/releases/luarocks-2.2.1.tar.gz http://luarocks.org/releases/luarocks-2.2.1-win32.zip  Those of you who installed LuaRocks 2.1.0 or later by using "make bootstrap" on Unix may upgrade by simply running:  luarocks install luarocks  What's new since 2.2.0:  * Improved compatibility with Lua 5.3 * `luarocks list --outdated` for listing modules with available upgrades * Assorted bugfixes  As usual, see the GitHub logs for detailed history and credits. And as always, all kind of feedback is much appreciated.  Thank you, enjoy!  </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Hisham</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-17T19:04:17</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115845">     <title>Re: Should the interactive interpreter insert "return" in readlinehistory?</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115845</link>     <description><pre> "caused by the user"?? I can't see how the interactive interpeter inserting extraneous tokens to its command history is "caused by the user".  Sometimes this list's tendency to try to "explain away" every quirk in Lua goes too far.  </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Hisham</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-17T18:43:37</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115844">     <title>Re: What's the rationale behind "for i=a,b[,c]"?</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115844</link>     <description><pre>2015-03-17 19:20 GMT+02:00 Sean Conner &lt;sean&lt; at &gt;conman.org&gt;: Tall and narrow.   </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Dirk Laurie</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-17T17:24:55</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115843">     <title>Re: What's the rationale behind "for i=a,b[,c]"?</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115843</link>     <description><pre>It was thus said that the Great Dirk Laurie once stated:    "Maypole-formatted" code?     Only half-sarcasm.    -spc (The other half was earnest seriousness)    </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Sean Conner</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-17T17:20:23</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115842">     <title>Re: What's the rationale behind "for i=a,b[,c]"?</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115842</link>     <description><pre>2015-03-17 18:57 GMT+02:00 Sean Conner &lt;sean&lt; at &gt;conman.org&gt;:  [ some 30 lines of maypole-formatted code ]  "Was that sarcasm?" (Sheldon)   </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Dirk Laurie</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-17T17:07:39</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115841">     <title>Re: What's the rationale behind "for i=a,b[,c]"?</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115841</link>     <description><pre>It was thus said that the Great Choonster TheMage once stated:  Or ...  function range(low,high,delta)   local up    = function(v) return v &lt;= high end   local down  = function(v) return v &gt;= high end   local d   local cmp    if not delta then     if low &lt; high then       d = 1     else       d = -1     end   else     d = delta   end     if d &gt; 0 then     cmp = up   else     cmp = down   end    return function(s,v)     v = v + d     if cmp(v) then       return v     end   end,nil,low-d end  for x in range(string.byte("AZ",1,2)) do   print(x) end  for x in range(1,10,1) do print(x) end  for x in range(10,1,-1) do print(x) end  for x in range(string.byte("ZA",1,2),-1) do   print(x) end    -spc (And just skip the whole "for i = low,high ..." thing entirely)    </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Sean Conner</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-17T16:57:35</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115840">     <title>Re: What's the rationale behind "for i=a,b[,c]"?</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115840</link>     <description><pre> What about this?  local a,b,c = 1,10,nil for i = a, b, c or 1 do     &lt;mycode&gt; end   </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Choonster TheMage</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-17T10:57:12</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115839">     <title>Re: What's the rationale behind "for i=a,b[,c]"?</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lang.lua.general/115839</link>     <description><pre>  On 17/03/15 01:24 AM, Dirk Laurie wrote: local a,b,c = 1,10,nil for i=a,b,c do print(i) end -- doesn't work because of the explicit nil  :/ why's nil not a valid "no value" here? :/  So there's no easy way to do it, other than:  local a,b,c = 1,10,nil if c == nil then    for i=a,b do      &lt;mycode&gt;    end else    for i=a,b,c do      &lt;mycode&gt; -- we have to duplicate the code?!    end end  Which's bad due to duplicated code  </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Soni L.</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-17T10:45:31</dc:date>   </item>   <textinput rdf:about="http://search.gmane.org/?group=$group=gmane.comp.lang.lua.general">     <title>Search Engine</title>     <description>Search the mailing list at Gmane</description>     <name>query</name>     <link>http://search.gmane.org/?group=$group=gmane.comp.lang.lua.general</link>   </textinput> </rdf:RDF>
